facts.text: Appellant was Loco Foreman at Alambagh Loco Shed.
Shukla secured contract at the same place for removal of cinders from ash pits and for loading coal in June 1952.
Appellant demanded Rs. 400 per month from Shukla in order that Shukla may be allowed to carry out his contract peacefully without harassment.
Appellant told Shukla that he had been receiving monthly payment from previous contractor Ram Ratan.
Shukla refused to pay, leading to hostile acts by appellant.
On January 3, 1953, appellant again asked Shukla to pay monthly bribe; Shukla requested reduction due to smaller contract amount; appellant agreed to Rs. 375.
Shukla had no money then, asked for time; agreed to pay on January 8, 1953.
Shukla approached Deputy Superintendent of Police, Corruption Branch, gave information; statement recorded before magistrate; trap laid.
Raiding party: Shukla, magistrate, DSP, others went to Loco Yard; Shukla and Sada Shiv inside; rest at gate.
Shukla met appellant, informed brought money; appellant went out, to secluded place; asked for money; Shukla gave bundle of marked currency notes Rs. 375.
Signal given; raiding party arrived; magistrate asked appellant to produce amount; appellant took out notes from pocket and handed over.
Appellant admitted receiving Rs. 375 from Shukla but claimed it was a loan for clothing expenses of school-going children.
Appellant alleged he requested Kishan Chand for loan of Rs. 500; Shukla offered to advance Rs. 375 knowing his need.

Special Judge believed Shukla's evidence, corroborated; defence improbable; raised presumption u/s 4 PCA, not rebutted; convicted u/s 161 IPC (1 year RI + Rs.500 fine) and s.5(2) PCA (2 years RI), concurrent.
High Court upheld conviction on presumption not rebutted; did not consider prosecution evidence apart; reduced s.5(2) sentence to 1 year; concurrent.
Appellant had bank balance of Rs.1,600; salary Rs.600/month; children to school in March, no immediate need; planned daughter's marriage.
Unlikely Shukla would advance loan given relations.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.4(1) of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 is unconstitutional and ultra vires as violating Art.14 of Constitution.
When does statutory presumption u/s 4(1) PCA arise; does it require proof that gratification was by way of bribe?
What is the nature of onus on accused to rebut presumption u/s 4(1); is it lighter than prosecution's burden?

petitioner_arguments.text: S.4(1) PCA offends Art.14 as it violates equality before law.
Presumption cannot be raised merely on receipt of Rs.375; must prove paid/accepted as bribe; 'gratification other than legal remuneration' requires proving incriminating character.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.4(1) PCA; compared to English Prevention of Corruption Act 1916

petitioner_arguments.text: Onus on accused is not as heavy as prosecution; rebutted if reasonably probable explanation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Otto George Gfeller v. King; Rex v. Carr-Briant; Regina v. Dunbar

respondent_arguments.text: Classification under s.4(1) reasonable, based on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object of eradicating corruption.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar; A.S. Krishna v. State of Madras

respondent_arguments.text: 'Gratification' to be construed literally as satisfaction of desire; presumption arises on proof of receipt other than legal remuneration; no need to prove as bribe.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.161 IPC para 3; State v. Pundlik Bhikaji Ahire; Promod Chander Shekhar v. Rex

respondent_arguments.text: Onus as per Evidence Act s.3,4; 'proved' or 'disproved' requires court belief or prudent man standard.

court_reasoning.text: S.4(1) PCA does not violate Art.14; reasonable classification of public servants for bribery cases where proof difficult; rational nexus to object of rooting out corruption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature realised difficulty in proving bribery; evidence often tainted.

court_reasoning.text: Presumption arises on proof accused accepted gratification other than legal remuneration; 'gratification' not confined to bribe; includes money not legal remuneration; similar to 'valuable thing' clause.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If required proving as bribe, presumption futile.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming lighter onus for rebuttal, appellant's loan explanation not reasonably probable: bank balance Rs.1600, salary Rs.600, no urgency, unlikely from Shukla given relations; defence witnesses unreliable.

holdings.text: S.4(1) PCA constitutional, not violative of Art.14.
Presumption u/s 4(1) arises upon proof of acceptance of gratification (money) other than legal remuneration.
Appellant's explanation fails to rebut presumption; conviction upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14 permits reasonable classification with rational relation to object.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar challenge to statutory presumption under Madras Prohibition Act repelled.
Held gratification requires proof as bribe (Rajasthan HC).
Held gratification requires proof as bribe (Bombay HC).

precedents_cited.case_name: Otto George Gfeller v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Accused need not prove story fully; if breaks down, may convict.
Burden on accused less than prosecution; probability suffices.
Onus on accused relaxed to preponderance of probability.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of bribery; defines illegal gratification as motive/reward.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory presumption on acceptance of gratification; offence of criminal misconduct.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of 'proved'; court presumes fact unless disproved.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality before law; challenged as violated by s.4(1) PCA.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; High Court's order upheld confirming conviction under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) PCA with sentences to run concurrently.

key_quotes.text: Art. 14 does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation; no doubt it forbids class legislation but if it appears that the impugned legislation is based on a reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core test for Art.14 constitutionality upheld for s.4(1) PCA.

key_quotes.text: If the word gratification is construed to mean money paid by way of a bribe then it would be futile or superfluous to prescribe for the raising of the presumption.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects narrow construction; presumption arises on mere receipt.

key_quotes.text: We are prepared to assume... that even if the explanation given by him is a reasonably probable one the presumption raised against him can be said to be rebutted. But is the explanation given by him reasonably probable?
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Assumes lighter onus but finds explanation improbable.
